results.content:
I have done a few Udemy Python courses from Jose Portilla, so maybe I am just not used to this new instructor, but he seems to give poor example code in his lectures and move a little too fast. It also seems like he opts for the more pythonic or advanced loops when teaching new subjects, so it just adds to the confusion.

For example:


        for item in items:
            if item['name'] == name:
                return item


turns into:



        item = next(filter(lambda x: x['name'] == name, items), None)

I am sure that the second way is ultimately the better way and more common among experienced developers, but there are examples like this throughout his whole course where he over complicates part of the code that isn't even relevant to the new subject he is introducing, so you get lost quickly.

response.content:
Thank you for your review Perry, and for your feedback regarding going too quickly. I will go through the videos again and see where we can make it even better.

Regarding the syntax of the code, I explain in the course that using list comprehensions vs. filter is mostly a stylistic difference, but sometimes you will want to use filtering instead so that the code is more familiar to programmers in other languages. Particularly with REST APIs where your clients will usually be JavaScript programmers, this can be particularly helpful (in many teams, front-end and back-end developers will work on both codebases).

That said though, I'm gutted that you felt lost and the course was overly complicated. Thanks again for the feedback!

Kind regards,
Jose
response.content_html:
Thank you for your review Perry, and for your feedback regarding going too quickly. I will go through the videos again and see where we can make it even better.

Regarding the syntax of the code, I explain in the course that using list comprehensions vs. filter is mostly a stylistic difference, but sometimes you will want to use filtering instead so that the code is more familiar to programmers in other languages. Particularly with REST APIs where your clients will usually be JavaScript programmers, this can be particularly helpful (in many teams, front-end and back-end developers will work on both codebases).

That said though, I'm gutted that you felt lost and the course was overly complicated. Thanks again for the feedback!

Kind regards,
Jose

results.content_html:
I have done a few Udemy Python courses from Jose Portilla, so maybe I am just not used to this new instructor, but he seems to give poor example code in his lectures and move a little too fast. It also seems like he opts for the more pythonic or advanced loops when teaching new subjects, so it just adds to the confusion.

For example:

for item in items:
if item['name'] == name:
return item

turns into:

item = next(filter(lambda x: x['name'] == name, items), None)

I am sure that the second way is ultimately the better way and more common among experienced developers, but there are examples like this throughout his whole course where he over complicates part of the code that isn't even relevant to the new subject he is introducing, so you get lost quickly.

results.content: This is an excellent course on creating REST APIs in Python and Flask with exposure to a few other things like Postman, Git, and Heroku. What I really like about it is that it starts from the most straightforward implementation and then the instructor goes through a series of refactoring steps to make the application more modern and to use helpful third-party libraries. For instance, the first few iterations use lists and dictionaries to store items and handle user authentication. Then he introduces SQL and SQLLite before finally introducing SQLAlchemy. I had never actually seen user authentication handled in this manner although I had seen references to it. As a result I feel like I have a more well-rounded understanding of Flask applications. The instruction on REST APIs was just as thorough, including in-depth direction on using Postman to test APIs. Finally the author shows you how to add your project to GitHub and deploy to Heroku and Digital Ocean. Great stuff!
results.content_html: This is an excellent course on creating REST APIs in Python and Flask with exposure to a few other things like Postman, Git, and Heroku. What I really like about it is that it starts from the most straightforward implementation and then the instructor goes through a series of refactoring steps to make the application more modern and to use helpful third-party libraries. For instance, the first few iterations use lists and dictionaries to store items and handle user authentication. Then he introduces SQL and SQLLite before finally introducing SQLAlchemy. I had never actually seen user authentication handled in this manner although I had seen references to it. As a result I feel like I have a more well-rounded understanding of Flask applications. The instruction on REST APIs was just as thorough, including in-depth direction on using Postman to test APIs. Finally the author shows you how to add your project to GitHub and deploy to Heroku and Digital Ocean. Great stuff!

results.content: I really enjoyed the course. It covers a lot not just about API development, but also how to deploy the api service application. It is probably the best flask api service tutorial i have seen. Its a 5 star rating for me.

results.content: First, it's an excellent course. I learned a lot about the Flask REST API from concept to implementation (deploy to servers). results.content:
This was a great course since it included so many different areas of instruction and follow-along opportunities.  As a 'tactical' Python developer I enjoyed the review of Python since it helped me understand the why's of a few Python features.  The Flask Python app solidified my knowledge of that library and the JWT and JWT Extended libraries add features that go beyond just producing web pages or returning data.  The steps from the direct use of a local sqlite database, to refactoring for SQLAlchemy, and then to the Postgres integration was easy to understand.  Finally, I really found the deployment sections to be really useful.  There is a lot of experience shared in there that will save me a lot of time instead of figuring things out by myself.

The instructor is great too, explaining what he is doing and why.  He has all his code available on Github and several resources on his website.  I would definitely take his courses again.

results.content:
I feel that the presentations, while basic, are complete enough to give anyone a good intro to Python. I like how the presenter asks questions and pauses for an appropriate time to allow people to consider the question. Very well done. The -1 star is only for the same sorts of console issues with presentations, all just personal preferences for me.

Updated review. The initial review was very early on in the course. I've now finished the course, and using this knowledge, I've already written another REST API for a personal project. I did, of course, go back and refer to the existing work, but the understanding I gleaned from the course made it much more than just copy and paste. 

Jose is a wonderful presenter, and I have nothing bad to say about this course. Additionally, Jose has a personable personality, and none of the videos were dry or hard to focus on, the atmosphere was a friendly one.

If you're brand new to programming, you may need to replay some videos to keep up, but that's part of the learning experience.

Thanks Jose. I'll be seeing you (literally) in two other of your courses I've purchased.

Probably the best online course I've taken. It explain very well the basics about REST and APIs, as well as the steps for testing while developing them.

Some prior experience with programming is very helpfull for this course. If that is not your case, you'll have to make more effort to understand the course (python refresh/update is in Section 1), and study harder during it.

The teacher is always available to answer your questions, and promptly responds in a matter of hours.

What could be improved: maybe improve the ORM part with SQLAlchemy. I found it a bit difficult as I never worked with ORMs before.

TEACHING skills of this young fellow are amazing. First I am mostly bored when learning new stuff because once you learn one programming language things are almost the same. But, this guy made my learning experience interesting and can get enough. First of all, lectures are not just thrown to explain how python works, instead he thoroughly made lessons to explain key concepts and prepare you for advanced concepts. I read that one student complains because he shows you stuff then in another example he shows you a little differently. Only inexperienced guys think this is the wrong approach where in fact it is how it should be done - it is called refactoring. To support this good work I'll buy all of the courses of this young brilliant teacher to give him support and to always do his best. By this course you wont regreat it :).

results.content:
Very good, but a little fast, as in -- explaining things in terms of why is always good, even in "refreshers". 

Really, this is the total basics in part 1 and you should explain that ":" is used instead of "{" as in other popular languages like Javascript or java. 

Explain that ":" is used as a representation of the word "then" because it allows us to speak to what happens next ... etc. 

Just a little more human explanation, relatable explanation.

I am halfway through and this course is really engaging, largely owing to the instructor's instruction approach. Explanation is spot-on with many "Pause the video and give it a try first" moments. I really like that because it helps the knowledge flow in and provides more hands-on exercises which for sure is very helpful. I can see that the course is carefully designed for better teaching instead of just demonstration. Video and audio quality (1080p) is great as well. Btw I just love the one-dark color scheme. I have been using it on VS Code for over a year now.  : )

Maybe more projects can be added in the future. Looking forward to it and other courses~

results.content:
For a thought, for the python refresher on the more advanced topics it would be nice to know the why ... for example decorators ... what is the real use example and why is it used ... i. e. for a loop, we know it is to iterate over a set of data.   

Second, for the follow along some areas Jose moves too fast on the switching between tools and I find myself pausing the video some to keep up, or rewinding the video.  Not a bad thing since we can rewind but if we are to code along there are extra steps to keep up.

results.content:
I'm pretty disappointed by the course contents. Description states 'no more to copy-pasting code that you don’t understand' but the course is full of exactly that. The main focus is to build a toy project and not to give insights into principles and structure of the application.

What you're NOT going to find in this course:
- Any compehensive (or even brief) overview of instruments in use (Flask, SQLAlchemy) with respect to functionality, entities, common use cases. Any attempt to use these instruments outside the toy project requires reading through documentation. It's rare of the teacher to step away from the particular code and describe a greater scheme of things.
- At least basic discussion of principles, technologies and protocols in use (HTTP, SQL, JWT, WSGI, ...). With no prior knowledge of database and web architecture the course is likely to turn into a code copy-pasting routine.
- Good practices. You're likely to leave this course with an impression that it's perfectly OK to store users' passwords in plain text (it's not). I'm not qualified to judge many used other design choices, but this one has immediately stroke me.

In short, this course seems easily replacable with a few 'Quickstart' pages on packages/instruments websites. It's, however, valuable as an overview of a full stack of technologies needed to creade a web API. But any deviation from the course, even to a newer release of any component will require learning many things from scratch.

results.content:
Firstly the biased bit, Jose's Scottish, I'm Scottish. It was nice to be taught in a familar accent so that was a thoroughly pleasant surprise. 

On the course itself, I knocked a half a star off it for the simple reason of the Flask-JWT section (it doesn't work with an anaconda based install). Being such an aged library, I ran into frustrations by using flask-jwt-extended off my own back before the course got to that section (my fault, not Jose's) and Petar the TA was there to assist me.  Turnaround time on questions was great. The course taught me a lot and focused on APIs rather than jinja2 templates for sites that most people would be doing in react/vue/svelte today anyway.  ...and that takes it back up to a thoroughy deserved 5 stars. 

Throughout the duration of this course I bought another couple of Jose's courses because of the effort and quality he's put in. 

This course is not short, nor overly long. I would recommend both this course and Jose generally. ..and a massive shout out to Petar too for the help in the Q&A section.

results.content: The thing I appreciated the most about the course is that the pace is faster than most others. I often found myself bored in other courses because there wasn't enough new material quickly enough. This course, however, delivers plenty of content and doesn't usually go over uselessly lengthy explanations. Besides that, the instructor is friendly and easy to understand. He has quality recordings and kept me engaged with the course. I would recommend this to anyone who's done python before and who wants to get into REST APIs with Flask, even if you don't know everything about lambdas or filter functions (there is a helpful section to bring students up to speed on the aspects of python used in the course).

results.content:
If I knew before this course was so amazing I'd have done it before!
The instructor is an awesome guy, with great knowledge about the subject and also very didactic. Clear explanations, comprehensive and well connected exercises.
As someone who came from embedded systems development and were willing to know more about APIs using my already acquired knowledge in python aiming to use it on IoT and connected devices, it just fitted like a glove.
I'm even considering learning much more around Web development and work with it for improving my knowledge around it.
I think this is the course to start with for anyone who want to "connect things" through the internet, if you pay close attention and use your creativity, it will be possible to imagine ways of using this for web apps, mobile apps, IoT devices, Embedded devices and everything which needs to talk to a server.
I'm not a new IT pro, but Web Dev was not my field, I had a very low knowledge around it. I'd recommend it for begginers (that already know a bit of python) and also for experienced developers.
Totally above my expectations! Well recommended.

I'm even considering learning much more around Web development and work with it for improving my knowledge around it.
I think this is the course to start with for anyone who want to "connect things" through the internet, if you pay close attention and use your creativity, it will be possible to imagine ways of using this for web apps, mobile apps, IoT devices, Embedded devices and everything which needs to talk to a server.
I'm not a new IT pro, but Web Dev was not my field, I had a very low knowledge around it. I'd recommend it for begginers (that already know a bit of python) and also for experienced developers.
Totally above my expectations! Well recommended.

results.content:
Jose's teaching skills and experience really shines through in this course. It's moderately paced, his language is very easy to listen to and understand and completely free from "um" and "err".

He types tremendously fast and basically typo free which just adds to the joy of letting him walk you through complex solutions and making it look like a Sunday walk.

I've taken a few courses in web development with python and this is by far one of the best! I definitely recommend it to anyone curious of REST API building with python or even just python in general, since the python primer in it self is awesome. No one has managed to explain lambda to me so well before.

results.content:
Jose is fantastic at what he does. His method of teaching concepts, then testing, then explaining why things are the way they are, are very important in the process of learning. I come from a C# background, and while picking up the core python programming is not difficult, learning the tips and tricks along the way have been fantastic in helping me better understand the logical flow of things. Most instructors go straight to the "short way" of writing code, but Jose does it at length, and then simplifies as he revisits the code. 

This is critical in understanding core concepts. I am eager for him to release more courses in the future. I can also say as an experienced programmer, that his structure and organization for the way he writes his code is absolutely essential to be able to easily read and update your code in the future. 

My advice is to imitate this as much as possible, and really take the questions he asks in the videos seriously if you want to maximize your learning.

Most instructors go straight to the "short way" of writing code, but Jose does it at length, and then simplifies as he revisits the code.

This is critical in understanding core concepts. I am eager for him to release more courses in the future. I can also say as an experienced programmer, that his structure and organization for the way he writes his code is absolutely essential to be able to easily read and update your code in the future.

My advice is to imitate this as much as possible, and really take the questions he asks in the videos seriously if you want to maximize your learning.

results.content:
I've not finished this course yet but now want to thank Jose for the great work. These are some of the highlights of this course:

- Incremental Approach: The project sets up the RESTful API first with plain flask, then with the Flask-RESTful extension, stores the data first with an in-memory flavor, then upgrade gradually from sqlite+plain sql to SQLAlchemy. 

- Just-In-Time Sync Point: literally, just-in-time synchronisation point makes sure that my project works (at least it can't be ridiculously wrong :) 

It would be even greater if the lecturer attaches more specific references/blogs to each topic that is impossible to cover within the videos. Since Jose is very good at making things easy to understand, i'd like to know more about the big picture about the web-development tech stack and the recommended learning path, perhaps in another course video/blog article. 

Many Thanks once more 

Shihao

results.content:
This course was a good choice after taking Jose's comprehensive course on Python. Jose is an engineer with great experience and it shows in his lectures. He is also a good instructor and knows how to build up knowledge incrementally and in a pleasant manner.
Also Ammar, the teaching assistant, and Jose himself, are actively part of the course Q&A and answer questions within a few hours.
My only comment was that in the flask app that we built, the user passwords were stored unencrypted in the database and in a real world app, the passwords should probably be hashed and compared during the login endpoint. 
I have noticed that Jose keeps this course updated and adds a good deal of content when needed, so I am hoping that he will add material on hashing passwords, etc.
Thanks for a great course,
David

results.content: Gives you everything you need to get a robust Python based API up and running.  The course was created several years ago and as a result of the technologies used in the course evolving, everything done in the course doesn't exactly work straight away.  At first, I found this annoying but realized that troubleshooting some of the things that didn't work gave me a better understanding of how things were working and positioned me better going forward than if everything was seamlessly implemented.  Highly recommend the instructor, the pace and explanation of the content was perfect for me!

results.content:
Great python and flask course, going quite deep technically speaking.

Section 2 covering python is to my mind extremely valuable, even to those who are already familiar with the language (you can still x2 it). In the end, it will guide you through intermediate-to-advanced python concepts that are rarely covered in this kind of courses.

I appreciate the fact that there's a sequel to the course going deeper and covering concepts like schemas.

Slight issue : some code snippets, especially those related to flask_jwt_extended are a bit outdated, but it's manageable if you get help from the documentation or the Q&A section.

results.content:
I really enjoyed the content of this course and the way this instructor approaches the subject. There's a small introduction to Python but I recommend that you be familiar with the language, since its just a refreshment. 

In each section you'll be rewriting the same API over and over again, while this seems boring it kinda shows you what each Flask package is doing, you start by writing the API with pure Flask + SQLite, but the following sections always add a new package, which forces the code to be re factored and the end result is more friendly, readable, maintainable source code. This processes repeats itself until the last 2 sections, which deal with how to deploy the said API.

I'd also recommend to take his "Automated Software Testing with Python" parallel to this course, since it deals with Flask API testing. 

If there's only downside of this is that sometimes the instructors does things that are borderline unpythonic, like using an import inside an `if __name__ == "__main__":`.

response.content: Hey Markus, thank you for your review and your feedback! We really appreciate it. We're glad you enjoyed the course even with these issues! We'll be taking them onboard when the time comes to re-record this course later on!
response.content_html: Hey Markus, thank you for your review and your feedback! We really appreciate it. We're glad you enjoyed the course even with these issues! We'll be taking them onboard when the time comes to re-record this course later on!

results.content_html:
I really enjoyed the content of this course and the way this instructor approaches the subject. There's a small introduction to Python but I recommend that you be familiar with the language, since its just a refreshment.

In each section you'll be rewriting the same API over and over again, while this seems boring it kinda shows you what each Flask package is doing, you start by writing the API with pure Flask + SQLite, but the following sections always add a new package, which forces the code to be re factored and the end result is more friendly, readable, maintainable source code. This processes repeats itself until the last 2 sections, which deal with how to deploy the said API.

I'd also recommend to take his "Automated Software Testing with Python" parallel to this course, since it deals with Flask API testing.

If there's only downside of this is that sometimes the instructors does things that are borderline unpythonic, like using an import inside an `if __name__ == "__main__":`.

results.content: This is my fifth course from instructor Jose. Out of the now 42 courses I have completed on Udemy, this is the most clear instructions for Python I have gotten. In addition, I appreciate the depth of this course. It is not only covering everything Python and Flask, but also deployment, setting up DNS records, configuring SSL to enable HTTPS, and more. A true joy to follow.

results.content: Instructor is good, but this course is incomplete, gets to lecture 115, shows 95% complete, but there are no further lectures available. You are also required to purchase resources (server space etc.) which you don't get to use effectively as the courses end around the point you are setting these up. I follow the instructor on Slack and there is no mention to this course any longer. Very disappointed and annoyed to have paid for resources I did not use, due to a lack of course material. Update to this is that the course is now fully complete, unfortunately I personally lost impetus in this particular course and have moved onto other things, including another course by the same instructor, life just gets in the way sometimes. It is definitely a course worth doing, you will learn a lot.

results.content:
Jose is a great instructor, I loved the course cause it was the best content about Flask-RESTful model that I have found to understand and also practice. Congratulations mate.

Also, I would like to give some tips for a next course or improvement of that content.

First -> Would be great with you could have a section to explain how to organize a flask project, well I'm in section 6 now, may have this in the other sections, but anyways I would recommend to puts this content on the very beginning, after 'a full python refresher', cause on the internet there is a lot of content explaining about flask app structure, but would be great and helpful have the course instructor view about it. 

Second -> I would recommend a new course or a few new sections to build a project, from zero to hero, starting with flask app organization, the back end (this course main content), and the front-end, well I said a new course cause would be a lot of new content and I know that one is a RESTful-API course, not a Flask web app with RESTful-API course.

Third -> You do have Heroku deployment and server deployment. Now with DevOps practices,  would be great have some docker tips with flask app.

I hope you keep doing this amazing content.

kind regards mate!

This course covers the basics on Flask with the instructor's standard python-review at the beginning (padding the length of the course).

results.content:
Just what I wanted to know! Clear, concise, modern and using good practices like venv
However, as the course progresses, I'm getting more frustrated by a  lack of refactoring. The presenter says we shouldn't copy & paste but invariably does just that. Opportuinities are lost to introduce the 'with' statement for database access. No discussion of decoupling the database access from the flask API, at least in the early stages
A lot of these shortcomings are resolved when SQLAlchemy is introduced. More signposting of this would be welcome

results.content:
Updated review.
The course is divided into two parts: the first part is when Jose uses Atom, the second one with VS Code. The first part is much better because Jose speaks slower and explains better, he is not in a hurry, but in the second part, he is. I think he just increased the speed of his voice programmatically and that is why sometimes he speaks too fast. But I prefer the first part because of the voice speed, it is better for me to understand quickly and not to miss a lot of really important things (for a beginner like I am). I am the kind of man who prefers type the code and listen at the same time, so sometimes it was necessary to replay some videos from 2 part again and again.
Anyway, the course is great, I definitely buy the next course.

results.content:
I had some interest on creating REST APIs in Python so I did a bit of research and took this course. It was better than expected.

I expected the usual in an Udemy course but the teacher went deeper than most.

Besides teaching how to create a REST API, Jose go for the extra mile with:
- A Full Python refresher before starting with APIs
- Learning how to perform tests with Postman
- How to use Git
- How to deploy to Heroku
- How to deploy to our own server
- Security

I'm very happy with this course. If you're looking for any course to learn how to create REST APIs (and something more), look no further.

results.content:
Wonderful course. I just loved each part.

I followed several Python beginner courses but none of them equal the 'A Full Python Refresher' section of this one. If you know what are algorithms, variables and functions (the very basics of programming) so this section will lead you from likely nothing to intermediate.

The course is a practical exercise where each notion comes one after the other so it's veeery easy to understand everything, with no exception. Jose encourages every time to think by oneself, and lets the time for.

I have been a Sysadmin until last year and now I'm working as a DevOps on an Infrastructure As Code solution. Providing REST API is a big part of my job and this course helps me a lot to get into my new tasks.

I'm eager to start the Advanced one!

Thanks to Jose, which is the best pedagogue I've seen for programming.

results.content:
Fairly good. Narrative is sluggish at times, I often need to up the speed, especially with the questions posed as if waiting for some live response, this adds no extra benefit to the videos, as we can of course, pause the playback instead. 

Sometimes terminology used is not really helpful, such as "running" a method instead of "calling" a method. Additionally the idea of functions seem to be totally ignored, and method is used in all cases in a class or outside. While this isn't so important in writing the examples in this case, beginners could, in theory, end up with a confusion in terminology going forward in their coding learning if such terms are not properly used.

There is no doubt the Author knows his Python, but some of the choices in narrative and application, are quite questionable from a more experienced perspective. However, in the spirit of the course, this isn't necessarily such a big issue, except for the fact that this is not a Free course. As it is paid, I would expect a greater degree of accuracy and detail in some aspects.

results.content:
I have to say this is one of the best course I've ever had. 

I'd like to express my gratitude towards Jose. He has definitely put a lot of thoughts and efforts into this course. Every lecture is intuitive and intriguing, and Jose nearly always read my mind when I begin to have questions during the lecture and guide me to solutions. 

When I do have unsolved questions, Jose always responds me in the course Q&A immediately with detailed explanation, even if it's a silly question, not like some other courses that just leave some general or ambiguous comments.

The architecture of the course is also carefully designed, which leads you step by step and answers your question in the following section. And this course not only teaches you how to code, but also emphasises your styling and provides you with further knowledge and resources to expand your skills.

In short, this is definitely a 5-star course and I'm really grateful for all the help from Jose. Without further ado, I'll see you in the next one.

results.content:
For me, Flask is a pretty simple python library, I wanted to take a deep dive into Flask - with this course - so I could better understand other frameworks like tornado and Django. Many concepts transfer over. Picking Flask would familiarize me with the function and terminology of any back end python rest api framework.

This class was such a bonus! All lectures had good cadance and explanation.  The non-Flask topics in this class can help seasoned programmers remember python OOP, re/learn Flask/REST concepts, and about how to craft your python application for deployment. The full top-down look in the course shows you what it takes to create, test, register, deploy and retest a internet accessible API. 

Thanks

This class was such a bonus! All lectures had good cadance and explanation. The non-Flask topics in this class can help seasoned programmers remember python OOP, re/learn Flask/REST concepts, and about how to craft your python application for deployment. The full top-down look in the course shows you what it takes to create, test, register, deploy and retest a internet accessible API.

Thanks

results.content:
The course started off very well. The pace was a little slow, but content was substantial.
However as the api evolved to include SQLAlchemy I found the explanations lacking, and a lot of writing out the code just to follow and keep the application working.
This was especially true of the Postman additions for the store in section 6, where to create an item for a store you need a store id. Unfortunately this wasn't being returned anywhere and the student is left to guess at what increment the database primary key is at that time.
I ended updating the code to display this, but could see that it may have left some students in the dark. In a later section this is addressed but felt like an add in that would have been nice earlier.
The same is felt for the section11 where the postman global variable suddenly changed from 'jwt_token' to 'access_token' and the newly added endpoints were failing until I realized what had happened and changed the tests that were populating the variable.
Overall good content. I'm being picky but these are the differences between average and great courses.
results.content_html:
The course started off very well. The pace was a little slow, but content was substantial.
However as the api evolved to include SQLAlchemy I found the explanations lacking, and a lot of writing out the code just to follow and keep the application working.
This was especially true of the Postman additions for the store in section 6, where to create an item for a store you need a store id. Unfortunately this wasn't being returned anywhere and the student is left to guess at what increment the database primary key is at that time.
I ended updating the code to display this, but could see that it may have left some students in the dark. In a later section this is addressed but felt like an add in that would have been nice earlier.
The same is felt for the section11 where the postman global variable suddenly changed from 'jwt_token' to 'access_token' and the newly added endpoints were failing until I realized what had happened and changed the tests that were populating the variable.
Overall good content. I'm being picky but these are the differences between average and great courses.

response.content:
Hey Hassaan, thank you for your review and your feedback! I understand your concern of tackling things in different ways, but I would say we're starting off with a reasonable way of doing things, and refactoring and improving the code to show how you would add new features to a real app.

I know there's these two ways of doing courses: show the real-life development process, or show exactly how you would do it from the get go. Picking one over the other is always going to have some drawback and some benefit!

We hope you enjoyed the course anyway!
response.content_html:
Hey Hassaan, thank you for your review and your feedback! I understand your concern of tackling things in different ways, but I would say we're starting off with a reasonable way of doing things, and refactoring and improving the code to show how you would add new features to a real app.

I know there's these two ways of doing courses: show the real-life development process, or show exactly how you would do it from the get go. Picking one over the other is always going to have some drawback and some benefit!

We hope you enjoyed the course anyway!

results.content:
This course provides a good overview of using Flask and other components to create an API. I feel that this class, along with countless other classes, falls short in providing best practices for coding. For example, SQL Injection attacks and mitigation should at least be touched on when you start learning SQL. Also, the instructor himself in one video states that you should grab whether or not a user is an administrator from a config or database, but then proceeds to hard-code it. I would also like to see a brief best-practices on the app secret key (perhaps pull the key from an environment variable?).

But still: really good overview in using Flask, SQLAlchemy (with SQLite3), Flask-JWT/Extended, and Flask-RESTful.

The author shows you the hard way of doing things first, and then the easy way. With this approach, one should be able to explain what is going on behind the scenes in things link Flask-RESTFUL or SQLAlchemy.

results.content:
The first sections are a good python refresher - with a focus on the features of python particularly relevant to flask.

The next sections focus on building the flask server, security, DB etc. These are very well presented and really help in learning to use flask.

If you are already a flask user, it clarifies a lot of things about flask use and putting together a flask/authentication/db infrastructure. If your focus is on using flask then this is a great tutorial; if your focus is on understanding flask under the covers (i.e. what is really happening behind the scenes in python to create request and response objects; understand threading; understanding error handling; etc. then this is helpful, but really not the class you are looking for. It is for a user of flask, not someone who wants to extend/alter flask functionality

results.content:
Is a really good course for starting, yet i can stress this enough, if you really want this course, grab it on discount, is just no worth the price, IMO, really good as a warmup, but not good for the real deal.

The part of selfpublishing is great, but is literally in the middle of the course instead of the end, which IMO breaks the order of the course, even if the JWT-Extended version was done later, i feel the sections should have actually be swapped out.

They also don't tell you that like, 80% of the digital ocean publishing section can be done on a VM, the other 20% is about paying services, and at the end of the day you may not use digital ocean, you may use linode or something else, so, that feel more like i bought an ad panflet from digital ocean and the other services, rather than learning how to self publish for real.

Overall not a bad course, but it needs a rework for sure

results.content:
I have been enjoying the training thoroughly! I would have liked if the pace was a bit faster. However I do agree and understand there could be freshers who would be taking this course.

I being a trainer myself who has extensively worked on Perl & Powershell, I appreciate the kind of effort that has taken to make this training lucid and easy to understand. The example, the quality of content, the voice over and the practice sessions. 

Everything is perfect, highly recommended for anyone wanting to learn python along with flask!

For newbies on windows, I would recommend to use Notepad++ as your primary editor along with the Python. Try and type all the examples along with the course. That will make your learning experience better and cement what you learnt.

results.content: Overall it is a good course. However, towards the end I feel like there is a bit tooo much stretching out of the course, that is not only of no benefit but adds to a new learners confusion. The teacher teaches a concept one way then changes it up in the following lesson. Not really a good method for new learning because the idea is to grasp a straightforward and too the point way of doing things, as opposed to "hey, here is one way to do it, and there is another way you can do, and also this way too". For beginners courses teachers should simply stick to the best or most common way to do things so students can focus on implementation. Towards the end of the course was a let down because it changed so much that my application just wouldn't work and I got lost trying to keep up with the constant unnecessary changes that could have just been done from the start. The stretching out of course ti keep introducing change totally ruined my  momentum. Spoiler to be honest. Its a good course but the teaching method losses focus of its audience towards the end. Nevertheless I learned something.

Hey JJ, thank you for your review. I'm gutted that you feel the later sections spoil the course. Deployments are a tricky one, and it was difficult to decide whether to add the code earlier on (even though it wasn't needed), or to add the code while deploying (which is what you'd normally do).

We're glad you enjoyed the course anyway!

I'd recommend to anyone who wants to grasp the basics of writing a Restful Flask application. You also end up with extra lessons around security/DNS/deployment and also a full python refresher which helped me lots. A good quality course.

results.content:
As a professional developer, I really enjoyed learning a new methodology in this course. Often when I look at coding courses, I find lessons which cater well to absolute beginners, but are monotony for more experienced developers who are just looking to expand their toolbox. I was very happy to discover that was not the case here.

Jose explains things clearly, but does not bog you down with needless simplifications. He assumes his students are also intelligent people and jumps right in with a real world project. He leaves the door open for an advanced coder to play with the style and add their own functionalities, while still absorbing the core practices at hand.

I was very pleased with this course and will certainly return for more.

results.content: Amazing course! Jose focuses on breadth, introducing a wide range of technologies that are compatible with Flask, and provides concrete examples when appropriate. Having watched some videos about building a REST API with Node.Express, it's nice to see things in a different context in python. Furthermore, you really see that there is use for most of the concepts discussed in the python refresher. Finally, a lot of the professional insight is very handy as well. Props to you Jose, I am very thankful! I look forward to starting the Advanced REST API course very soon!

results.content:
I got this course a few months ago, and although it took me some time to get into it, I believe this course is highly informative, and practical in professional and even personal use. Jose has a clean, and straight to the point approach, while answering questions along the way as they come up. 

There are times there might be an added benefit to describe in depth what some terms mean, and why standards are the way they are, but as a student, I believe it was partly my responsibility to find this information on my own. 

Overall, Jose gives you a organized, straightforward approach to API's. He equips you well to learn API's, and allows you to move forward and create your own API's. I am very satisfied with this course, and I would definitely recommend!
results.content_html:

results.content:
This was a very good, comprehensive course that went beyond the core coding concepts. As a QA Automation Engineer, I appreciated the fact that José incorporated testing (via Postman) all along the way. 

One minor area could be improved upon would be if each lesson's code could have a Git tag so one could choose to check out incremental code points within a section. Otherwise, the course was very good and I laud José's responsiveness to a few issues I had along the way. 

Highly recommended!

One minor area could be improved upon would be if each lesson's code could have a Git tag so one could choose to check out incremental code points within a section. Otherwise, the course was very good and I laud José's responsiveness to a few issues I had along the way.

Highly recommended!

The deployment part is particularly powerful.

Well done. HIGHLY recommended.

results.content: Give it a go with Jose! I thought the course was about using APIs when I started taking it but it's actually about creating APIs lol. Very informative and sequential. Takes you from intermediate python knowledge to making APIs and understanding all the web components that use them. It's difficult for an intermediate level course to know what knowledge to assume so I don't envy the task of the instructor, but be ok with doing quick outside reference research to brush up on random web development or programming topics you might not know.

results.content:
the REST APIs with Flask and Python course is really amazing in how it takes me through the key issues in building a web app.  Making sure the basic building blocks of authentication are there and progressing to advanced topics of dealing with foreign objects in the database is pretty amazing.

I have always found bits and pieces of the Flask puzzle online, but this course lays it out as a cogent and cohesive picture.  I know all the pieces are there and feel confident in investing my limited time into something I think will give me a good ROI.  I have stopped on many other tutorials when I realized it was either old or incomplete and wouldn't move me forward the way I wanted, but this series has been pretty amazing.  

I also think it is rare to have such an invested instructor who genuinely cares (and probably never sleeps).

response.content: Hi Claudio! We appreciate you leaving your feedback. A lot of information being taught in school are information freely available in books from public libraries and other sources. In this case, a lot of information is available for free from other sources like YouTube. However that does not make courses like this completely irrelevant. It is the style of teaching and other information that is being shared that makes this course valuable. Some people prefer a more in-depth dive of topics while some can live on a quick skim through lectures. Either way, we hope your coding journey on youtube produces awesome results! results.content:
Great Course, definitely a lot of good stuff, including a great Python language reference in the refresher with clear and concise explanations .

There is a very solid foundation for building REST APIs with Flask in this course, including a lot of bonus material, some of the more advanced concepts on the Python language, Postgres setup, uWSGI and NginX configuration for DigitalOcean deployment and ssh.

I would definitely recommend the course, it goes above and beyond.

results.content:
Without any doubt, this course is awesome!
Jose did a great work explaining how to implement a REST API using Flask, how to use JWT, SQLAlchemy, etc.

If you're a beginner, there's a section to help you to understand the basics of Python. If you're coming from another language, you can quickly understand how to implement a REST API using Python + Flask, because the explanations are concise.

results.content:
Edit: Just finished the course and it has been a great journey! I have learned a lot. Thanks Jose for this great course! 
End of edit

This is a great course for learning REST API with Flask. Gives the bigger picture, how to properly design APIs with flask-restful, how to protect them with JWT, and how to make APIs to  perform CRUD operations using sqlalchemy and sqlite. 

Overall the lessons are quite enjoyable. I have already bought the advance REST api course by the same instructor. 
The only criticism I can think of is it would have been a bit nicer if the videos on JWT were updated to show how to use extended JWT library. The instructor added a new section for it, but the original videos still use JWT. So at first it can be a little confusing. But it made me read the extended JWT docs and it took only about 30 mins to an hour until I was able to use it. So, not a big deal. 

Overall it's a great course and I highly recommend it.

Overall the lessons are quite enjoyable. I have already bought the advance REST api course by the same instructor.
The only criticism I can think of is it would have been a bit nicer if the videos on JWT were updated to show how to use extended JWT library. The instructor added a new section for it, but the original videos still use JWT. So at first it can be a little confusing. But it made me read the extended JWT docs and it took only about 30 mins to an hour until I was able to use it. So, not a big deal.

Overall it's a great course and I highly recommend it.

Overall is good as a start point for learning end to end REST API with Flask.

Could be better if we could:
1. Focus on best practice e.g. API conventions, database conventions.
2. Present high-level picture before going low-level details, e.g. project structure, what are the relationship between different tools when setting up your own server
3. for basic stuff the explanation is clear but for some advanced topics, the explanation is not, e.g. when talking about the circular import

Overall is good but could be better.

results.content:
Excellent course.  Very well-planned out.  It starts with the very basics and in every section, it builds upon the material covered in the previous ones.  By the end of the course, you have a pretty clear idea of how to build a CRUD Api using Flask, Flask-RESTful, Flask-JWT, and Flask-SQLAlchemy.

Besides teaching you how to program a REST Api, the course covers other important topics, such as:

1.	 How to setup and use Git and Github.
2.	How to deploy your REST Api using Heroku.
3.	How to deploy your REST Api using DigitalOcean.  This was particularly interesting to me, since the instructor provided detailed information on how to install everything needed in ubuntu, how to setup nginx, how to configure users and permissions, how to add rules to the ubuntu firewall, etc.
4.	How to setup SSL for your DigitalOcean deployment using certificates generated for free at CloudFlare.

Overall, the course is very complete and the instructor takes care of covering all you need to code and deploy the application.
results.content_html:
Excellent course. Very well-planned out. It starts with the very basics and in every section, it builds upon the material covered in the previous ones. By the end of the course, you have a pretty clear idea of how to build a CRUD Api using Flask, Flask-RESTful, Flask-JWT, and Flask-SQLAlchemy.

Besides teaching you how to program a REST Api, the course covers other important topics, such as:

1. How to setup and use Git and Github.
2. How to deploy your REST Api using Heroku.
3. How to deploy your REST Api using DigitalOcean. This was particularly interesting to me, since the instructor provided detailed information on how to install everything needed in ubuntu, how to setup nginx, how to configure users and permissions, how to add rules to the ubuntu firewall, etc.
4. How to setup SSL for your DigitalOcean deployment using certificates generated for free at CloudFlare.

Overall, the course is very complete and the instructor takes care of covering all you need to code and deploy the application.

results.content:
The Instructor has a TERRIBLE habit of asking "Now what do you think will happen if we ...?", and then pausing for an extended period of time, AS IF I WAS THERE TO GIVE AN ANSWER! 

Hopefully you're aware that I am NOT in the video with you and CANNOT respond. Please stop wasting my time by asking me what I think. It's like trying to sit through educational programming for toddlers - where they ask the same questions, attempting to stimulate a response from the child. 

It's exhaustingly boring, and a little insulting. I can form "I wonder if..." statements on my own. I can also google the answer or try it out on my own if I'm truly curious.

Even on 2X playback speed, I find that I still need to skip ahead so that I can get past your long pauses and "jokes about space Roth being an astronaut".

I would be much happier if you edited out all the "fluff" that you think is making your videos better, and just got to the point. I have control of the pause button, access to the Q&A, and I'll use it if I need to. 

Each one of your videos could easily be cut in half.

A video should be directed like a book, not a 1 on 1 session.

The next time you feel the impulse to ask: "What do you think this function might do if ...?"
Re-phrase it to: "YOU MIGHT BE WONDERING WHAT this function might do if ..., AND THE ANSWER WOULD BE ..." 
Get right to the point. 
Don't pause. 
Just give me the information I paid for.

I gave you 2 stars because the content is there, and I learned a FEW things, and I think 2 stars is rather generous, because I would expect to (and have) learned a lot more than a FEW things after an hour and a half of video lectures. 

I'm pretty close to asking for a refund and finding another course to learn from. I'll go through a few more videos, but this is terrible.

results.content:
Jose know his code, but as the course approaches more complicated concepts certaiin explanations get blurry:
1-  The use of method, object and instance is mixed.  Jose knows his stuff, but he needs to be detailed when refering to these concepts
2-  When explainiing @classmethod and @staticmethod he is not as clear communicating the idea as much as the previous tutorials.  I personally have Youtube videos that explained the subject clearly.
3-When explaining (Inheritance) and how to use @classmethod, he totally over-complicates the example given to an extent the student get's lost.  This is not nessecary as simple examples need to given for the student build their knowledge on.  Jose, goes in loops when explaining.

I will update my feedback when complete the course.

results.content:
The course is not bad but I still do not recommend it for the following reasons:

1) The teacher does not divide the project correctly, for example: do a big project with user login / registration and you can not really use the project for another purpose because each part depends on the other part and it complicates everything, it would be better if there was a split of the parts into many tiny projects when possible Connect each other in a friendly way.

2) The teacher does not explain enough about the process and the reasons for each line of code.

3) Do not expect to get answers to your questions - it takes a lot of time and the question is no longer relevant in most cases (because you want to move forward)

results.content:
I found this course to be extremely frustrating - WOULD NOT RECOMMEND unless you're an advanced python programmer and proficient in object oriented programming. Unfortunately I can't get my money back because I waited too long between purchasing the course and actually taking it.

"review" section is super-weird - if you know python well, you don't need review. If you don't know python well, it is a HORRIBLE section that does a very poor job of explaining fairly advanced python stuff like lambdas, filter fuctions, dictionary comprehensions, etc. and there are very few hands-on exercises.

section 71 is a trainwreck - takes nice, clear code and obsfuscates it beyond comprehension of anyone but an advanced python programmer.

section 94 is also a disaster - so confusing.

results.content:
This course is super disappointing. It only scatches the surface. Everything is just super superficially explained. Most of the time this guy just copies the standard tutorials from a website and reads them out loud...

Also 90% of the material is not related to flask - which is kind of funny considering the title of the course - which indeed is misleading.

On the other hand, trivial concepts (such as sudo) are elaborately explained which is super annoying. To the author: Your viewers are not stupid!

Also, stop saying "okay" after every three sentences. 

Conclusion: This is just a typical udemy course - not more worth than 10 euros.

response.content: Hey Thomas, thank you for your feedback. I understand what you are saying about the course contents, although I strongly disagree. The course is about building REST APIs with Flask, it's not a course about the Flask library on its own. The very course subtitle talks about multiple Flask extensions that are covered (I guess that's what you mean by the unrelated material in your review). With that in mind though, I'll take your comments into account when we come to re-record the course and see if there's more pure Flask content that we can cover.

results.content:
Prior to purchasing this course I had tried out youtube video courses and found them good but generally were either out of date or focusing on very general topics with little explanation of what they were doing and why. For example, Jose goes through SQLite and you see the usefulness but that its got a lot of repetitive code and then builds upon our knowledge and introduces SQLAlchemy.
Overall an excellent course and well worth whatever price you have paid.

The only criticisms I have regard some of the earlier exercises, the direction of what was expected was a little vague and I was scratching my head trying to understand what was being asked of me. This literally happened only once or twice, and I do believe the exercises are a valuable training tool for students.

results.content:
This is a really great course. It takes you step by step from zero knowledge about Python to developing a RESTful API using Flask for Python. The instructor is thorough, explains every thing plainly and is very knowledgeable about the subject.

There are some parts missing, although they were mentioned to be in the last section which is not there, like caching and performance.

Also, some advanced subjects are not discussed like rate limiting and the API security mentioned in the course is JWT which is not very secure in my opinion. I also, did not like the part of using Digital Ocean for hosting as it was very complicated and it would have been much better to tackle some more popular hosting service like AWS or Google Cloud hosting.

All in all, this is a great course. I just hope they re-include the missing parts and consider more popular hosting examples.

So many topics I have been able to use (i.e., decorators), however, I admit I never really understood what was going on. I do now. The review has been greatly appreciated.

(final update) just finished the course. Met ALL my expectations and more. I feel like I learned everything about this subject, and what I didn't learn, Jose gave me the tools to find it. Highly recommend!

results.content:
This is a very through course and worth EVERY penny and minute.  The Python refresher alone makes the course worthwhile.  It covers many advanced concepts that are unique to Python and make it a great language.  Each concept is developed from basic implementation and advances to the final stage.  Also, the deployment sections are very helpful.  It rare that a course like this actually goes all the way to read world deployment.  VERY VERY helpful.

On the downside, there are 2 very important sections missing.  

First: What is Flask?  I had no experience with it when I started and I'm still not sure what it is other than a Python module.  Why would I choose it?  What makes it a better framework that anything else available? 

Second: What is REST?  What are the conventions that we should be following to build a standard restful service?  I had to Google those concepts.  Below is a list of suggested/required (?) end points I found.  But, that idea is never presented.  

Index	   /dogs	         GET   List all dogs
New	   /dogs/new	   GET	Show new dog form
Create	/dogs	POST	   Create   a new dog, then redirect somewhere
Show	   /dogs/:id	   GET	Show info about one specific dog
Edit     /dogs/:id/edit	GET	Show edit form for one dog
Update	/dogs/:id	   PUT	Update particular dog, then redirect somewhere
Destroy	/dogs/:id	   DELETE	Delete a particular dog, then redirect somewhere
